<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_close_error:
```c
static void
connection_close_error (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *emsg)
{
  connection->stop_with_error = true;
  connection->discard_request = true;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (NULL != emsg)
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              "%s\n",
              emsg);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) emsg; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  MHD_connection_close_ (connection,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_WITH_ERROR);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function body above is the only place in this snippet that performs function calls. There is no direct call to connection_close_error from within itself (no direct recursion). The two function/macro calls present are MHD_DLOG (a logging macro) and MHD_connection_close_. MHD_DLOG is a logging facility and is unlikely to cause an indirect call back to connection_close_error; it can be deprioritized for recursion investigation. The primary potential for indirect recursion is the call to MHD_connection_close_: investigators should check the implementation of MHD_connection_close_ to determine whether it (directly or indirectly) calls connection_close_error, creating a recursion cycle. No function pointers or other call sites appear in this fragment that could introduce indirect recursion, and the preprocessor handling of emsg only mutes a compiler warning and does not affect call flow.
